top_comment.text:
Lots of emotion in this video. Allusions to things not true, but beckoning. 
The TNT/Bomb explosion is bogus; it all depends on the size of the TNT 
explosion. A bay in NC - no, sorry, too high, too far from water, not a big 
enough hole. "The uranium rich secondary" - well, rich with depleted U-238, 
not fissionable, not very dangerous, even if someone stored it in their 
barn. The lithium deuteride won't ever do anything. What does the 
radioactive Boy Scout have to do with bombs? He wasn't even trying for 
that. Radium isn't fissile; americium is, but how many detectors would you 
need to scrap? You know the reasons that "we can build a weapon...but not 
predict the weather"; how does that affect what we should do? (And we can 
do better than a "few minutes ahead of time".)  What do the proclivities of 
the Japanese religions have to do with the bomb, except you get to use 
Hirohito's phrase?  Did he not see the destruction in his own royal city, 
which killed more people without any atomic weapon?

These non-sequiturs bother me.  I think your conclusion is brilliant, and 
sensible, but not because of the evidence you site.  Perhaps it isn't 
really evidence, but just what you think is motivating. Not original, 
certainly, but well put.﻿
top_comment.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
I believe the Tsar was fission-fusion-fission, with the last fission 
deleted with the lead tamper.  Could be wrong, but it was a brute force, 
conservative design done in 90 days.  US designers said, after studying it, 
that they could have done the same with half the weight, and probably could 
have.  No real need, though, and too busy in their own directions.

OK, didn't realize you were referring ti reactors there.  Perhaps we should 
say, "Barely under control."  :).
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
You are correct(the Tritium part). Wasn't the Tsar Bomb originally designed 
as a "Fission-Fusion-Fusion-Fusion device" The U-238 was replaced in one or 
more of the tertiary fuel rings with lead. I think that's what you just 
said? Good stuff. Oh and controlled fusion is done in a lab(as you know). 
Comparing uncontrolled fusion to an M-80 is maybe not the best analogy, but 
I get the point. Thanks for keeping my brain active=)
comments.author: fla playa

comments.text:
No tritium in the fuel; that's created by neutron bombardment of lithium. 
Yes, you can use a lead tamper, but yu loose the explosion boost when the 
U-238 fissions with high-energy ("fast") neutrons; that is often the major 
part of the explosion; Tsar Bomba would have increased yield by 100% with 
the originally designed U-238 tamper. Your phrase "uncontrolled nuclear 
fusion" owes nothing to nuclear fusion; an M-80 exploding is uncontrolled.

Fusion fuel has nothing to do with fission fuel. You can mix and match, 
except that you have to start with fission to create a neutron and 
heat/pressure source.
comments.author: puncheex2

comments.text:
I thought I was correct with my statement "thought the secondary was 
Lithium Deuteride  and Tritium". I stand corrected with the fact that you 
just pointed out U-238 is used as a 'tamper'. BUT lead can also be used. 
Seems U-238 is almost exclusively used, and can actually undergo tertiary 
fission due to it's interaction with neutrons right along side of fusion 
adding to the  "out of this world power that is: uncontrolled nuclear 
fusion"

comments.text:
+mrdean171 You speak of Japanese soldiers being the toughest soldiers out 
there, perhaps the more fanatical compared to American GIs? Yes. Toughest? 
That is a long shot, The traditions of Bushido that permeated during 
Imperial Japan are matched by the sheer manpower/will of Russian forces. 
The strongest argument against the dropping of the bombs is the invasion of 
the Soviets. Russia at the time had just suffered extensive damage from 
Germany and had, through attrition, destroyed the German War machine. They 
caused German armies to completely capitulate, not even the American forces 
in Normandy, Sicily and North Africa could say the same. Germans were 
almost similar to Imperial Japan. Albeit, there was significant numbers of 
mass suicides upon American invasion of the Japanese colonial islands. 
There is also a significant number who just flat out surrendered. And if 
you say what you said is true, even though their Government and Emperor 
surrendered, the Japanese people would have kept fighting. Then all those 
letters of officers, sergeants and privates of the Imperial army are false. 
To a certain extent it can be shown how suicidal Japan was, however if that 
was completely the case as we like to point out then Japan would have never 
surrendered, if you base this on Opinion like you have.
     Also the Generals at the time new completely of all these 
consequences, politically speaking. These factors mentioned in previous 
statements were made by those Generals and heads of staff. I'm not 
pretending to now more than they did. I'm merely restating what they would 
reveal decades after the Decision to drop the bombs. The truth is also, 
that if it hadn't been for Truman's change of heart we would have kept 
dropping the bombs. Japan surrendered after Truman's decision to stop the 
bombing (at least that's what he himself revealed). Japan surrendered after 
the authorization of atomic bombing was suspended. We also can infer more 
upon Stalin's confidence  was that rushing the Russians to liberate China 
 would end the war. We also know through cracking the Japanese code 
(something achieved mid-WW2) that the successful Russian invasion of 
Manchukuo nearly coincides with the surrendering of Japan.  So perhaps it 
is just coincidence, that's up for you to make the final decision (of 
course based on your haste rational nothing changes your opinion). There 
was a significant timeline of the end game, the bombings, Russian invasion 
and then the surrendering. 
Perhaps nothing would have changed, who knows, but it is likely it would 
have changed. After the second bombing records still show that PM Tojo and 
the majority of the head generals still supported fighting to oblivion. The 
emperor didn't make his final decision until over a week after the bombings 
and then after the Russian invasion.
     What still concerns me is that we as Americans, the majority of us, 
would rather believe our actions are nearly almost justified in the end. We 
like to whitewash history and stay quite when it pictures America as the 
wrongful aggressor. We hardly ever speak of the true crimes against Native 
lifestyles and culture throughout the 19th century. Nor do we nations we've 
abused in Latin America. We only talk about our pride being shredded in 
Vietnam and not the herbicide and napalm warfare and don't even mention the 
brutality of the actions certain Army and Marine regiments against 
Civilians. The problem is that we rather be ignorant and clean our own 
footprints rather than accept what we did.
     If bombs work so well, atomic, nuclear or conventional, why did we 
give up at Pearl Harbor, why did the Vietnamese surrending after we dropped 
millions of tons of ordinance on Hanoi with B-52 bombers? Bombs don't do

argument. Neither surrender, not in the Blitz and neither in the 
Fire-bombings of Tokyo. That flaws the entire idea the reasoning behind the 
dropping of the bombs. Statistically speaking it is believed that the 
fire-bombings did more damage then the A-bombs did.

comments.text:
+Justin M
 First of all, I don't need to cite historical evidence because I'm not 
looking this shit up on a Wikipedia as I go. If you look at patterns of 
casualty rates you'll find the closer we got to Japan the higher they got. 
If we would have invaded the mainland, we would have found ourselves

on a scale 10,000 times bigger and you might be in the ball park for the

Also, you do realize that it also would have DEVASTATED the Japanese 
population right? On many islands we attacked over the civilians would jump 
off fucking cliffs before being under our rule. Are you really so god damn

I also find it funny how you think you know more about the situation than

comments.author: TheBrother171

comments.text:
+mrdean171 It's that type of American arrogance that makes us look bad 
abroad. If you do not realize this, Russia was already taking China from 
Japan, if you're smart its possible to not even invade Japan. They could 
not supply themselves without their 'colonies'. When we dropped the bombs 
Russia was taking Japan's only remaining source of raw materials. We could 
have saved many people on both sides with this strategy of seiging Japan 
rather than invasion. We had peace treaties planned that were not overly 
liberal and sympathetic to the Japanese. 
Secondly, you make yourself look bad when you compare your actions to the 
holocaust. By dropping the bombs we succumbed to the level of the Nazis and 
the Japanese in genocidal massacres of Jews and Chinese, respectively. I 
can understand the elimination of military targets, I don't mind bombing 
ports, roads, bridges, mines, factories, etc. What we should mind is the 
massacre of defenseless women, children and elders.
Finally, I don't understand how I'm ignorant when in your response to my 
statement lacked no historical evidence of the casualties we were rumored 
to have had. I'll give you some, We were predicted to lose over 1 million 
troops storming Japan. The original bombing target was Kyoto, the spiritual 
center of Imperial Japan. Until Truman specifically said to stop bombing we 
were prepared to drop more bombs, easily equaling more than 1 million. 
Truman himself, in his last report he made publicly, said there's anywhere 
from 200,000 to 1 million dead. Sadly despite as many records as we can 
find, some people were completely and instantaneously vaporized (so if it 
helps you justify our actions, the Japanese who were in Ground Zero 
probably felt no pain). You can check these facts out yourself, these are 
actually numbers reported by Truman and his military staff. The affects of 
the bomb has continued to leave its effects on Japan as cancer continued to 
circulate in families if it didn't kill them off initially. 
So I end this response by asking how I am in the end the ignorant one when 
in both my statement and my response to an arrogant child I provided basic 
facts which are able to find quite easily. It seems to me, my friend, that 
you need to backtrack and support yourself before spewing ignorance and 
making yourself seem dimwitted.
comments.author: Justin M

comments.text:

Many people forget that it wasn't the bombs or the Russians per say that 
ended the war, Emperor Hirohito himself (the human god-emperor of Japan) to 
have them lay down their arms. We had written an adjustment to our 
"unconditional surrender" to allow the Emperor maintain his throne, which 
would of likely allowed a peaceful end to the war. However, we decided to 
hold this information back.

Something interesting to note though, when we dropped the bombs Stalin 
himself was appalled, a man who would have later been discovered to have 
killed 20 million of his own people. He himself would not have believed we 
would drop the bombs. Given the long distance, the Generals in charge of 
campaign in Japan did not even need Executive approval to drop more bombs, 
but after Nagasaki was bombed Truman demanded Groves (the leading general 
incharge of the bombings) to stand  down with the words, "I don't want to 
kill anymore women and children". In the end we didn't give them a chance, 
in the end that's what we did, killed women and children, in the end those 
deaths were and still are on our hands. 

What's our greatest defense? We got our revenge for Pearl Harbor, over

comments.text:
Let's clean this up a little bit, shall we? Feel free to make your input -

At first, there was no invention but a discovery of nuclear fission and 
this did not have anything to do with weapons but merely scientific 
discovery, you see. Nuclear fission of heavy elements was discovered on 
December 17, 1938 by Otto Hahn and his assistant Fritz Strassmann, and 
explained theoretically in January 1939 by Lise Meitner and her nephew Otto 
Robert Frisch.

The research and development of the bombs however was a team effort, the 
Manhattan Project. Of course there were some previous research done by the 
German. Einstein had no part in this except for his warnings and his letter 
to president Roosevelt recommending the building of atomic bombs.

top_comment.text:
Eric Sclosser's assertions of an acceptable risk for nuclear weapons 
involved in accidents is HIGHLY misleading.  Not all the facts have been 
produced here.  

Having personally worked on Nuclear Weapons for 20 years I never once saw 
or heard of a nuclear weapon "accident" that occurred anywhere throughout 
the world.  Additionally, the DOE required a more than one BILLION to one 
chance of an accidental explosion for normal handling and operations on 
nuclear weapons NOT involved in an accident. This is to say that the only 
time a nuclear weapon risk factor is dropped to a one in a million chance 
is when the weapon itself is exposed to a highly abnormal condition, such 
is being on fire.

These risks are what the DOE places as broadly calculated acceptable risks. 
 This is NOT The actual risk of a nuclear weapon detonating.  Those are 
much, MUCH higher.

That said, you are 11,628 times more likely of being poisoned to death...﻿
top_comment.author: Jason Churchill

comments.author: JessicaEarlheart

comments.text:
To play devil's advocate (before I give you the answer that is...) why 
should you believe Mr. Sclosser either?  He gives no concrete references 
for his statements, nor does he seem any more credible than any average Joe 
on the internet (for example, me).  

Anyway, you should believe me because 1) my credentials are sound with over 
two decades of experience to back up my statements.  Mr. Sclosser has what? 
 A study?  An "investigation" for a book?

Also, a little internet search brought up one of the original Nuclear 
Surety program documents from 1997 (reviewed in 1999). 

http://fas.org/nuke/guide/usa/doctrine/doe/o452_1a.htm

This was an incredibly quick search and I didn't attempt to find anything 
newer (I'll leave that up to you for burden of proof if you're still biased 
toward Mr. Sclosser's assertions.

The specifics are as follows:
Nuclear Weapon Design Surety (keyword to Google btw) - 
-Nuclear Detonation Safety - This sub-bullet discusses the differing 
environments a nuclear weapon might be exposed to and the "acceptable" risk 
for detonation.

In short:
Normal Environment - One in a billion nuclear detonation per nuclear weapon 
lifetime.
Abnormal Environment - One in a million nuclear detonation per nuclear 
weapon per CREDIBLE accident or exposure to abnormal environments.

comments.text:
The most powerful nuclear device ever detonated was the Tsars bomb by the 
Soviet Union in the early 1960s. It was a 56 megaton thermonuclear warhead. 
A scaled down version of a 100 megaton device the Soviets planned to 
explode. It was detonated over Siberia. The Tsars bomb was a 5 stage 
thermonuclear device. In essence there is no limit to the yield of these 
devices. You could have a 7 8 9 or 10 stage device with yields of 1 2 or 3 
hundred megatons. Detonating such a powerful device would strip away a 
large proportion of the Earth's atmosphere.The only safe place to explode 
such a device would be far out into space.

a vacuum. Sound waves, which require air to travel, cannot.

1. Waited until the Soviet Union declared war on Japan on August 9 
- Because of the close proximity of the Soviet Union's entry into the 
Pacific War and the nuclear bombings, it is unclear over which one of these 
had the biggest impact to Japan's surrender. It is quite possible that it 
was purely the Soviet Union's entrance into the Pacific War that got the 
Japanese surrender when you compare the date Japan surrendered (August 15) 
to the date the second atomic bomb was dropped (August 9). This lengthy 
timeframe may suggest that atomic bombs did not play a key role in the 
surrender. By contrast, the Soviets invaded Manchuria on August 9, and by 
August 15, occupied it and threatened the Japanese home islands. 

2. Waited for the US sea blockade to end the war 
- A sea blockade was more effective than a US invasion to end WWII. The 
Japanese military were eagerly anticipating a US invasion so they could 
inflict American casualties. If the US publicly denied an invasion of Japan 
it would mean no American casualties and would signal to Japan that defeat 
was inevitable. The US Navy was against an invasion and strongly backed a 
sea blockade for this very reason. Fleet Admiral Chester Nimitz and Gen. 
Carl Spaatz of the USAAF believed that in the event of this scenario, 
Japanese leaders would ultimately give in. (Remember, Japan had no navy and 
no air force to relieve the blockade). 

3. Given a public message to Japan saying that the imperial family would be 
saved from war crimes trials 
- The Japanese military resisted primarily to defend the imperial family 
from post-war prosecution. Japanese military leaders believed the Allies' 
"unconditional surrender" meant that the imperial family would be powerless 
and face the court. This was obviously not the case, but Truman failed to 
tell Japan this. Gen. Douglas MacArthur knew the importance of the imperial 
family to the Japanese military and therefore urged Truman to let Japan 
know about the fate of their imperial family if Japan accepted the 
unconditional surrender. 

If Truman was truly humane and serious about "saving lives" he would've 
tried these alternatives before resorting to nuclear bombs. This is why I 
believe Truman purposely used nuclear weapons to intimidate the Soviet 
Union. It wasn't a coincidence that they were dropped around the same time 
the Soviet Union entered the Pacific War. 

I hardly think deliberately destroying Hiroshima and Nagasaki's hospitals, 
universities, high schools, primary schools, kindergartens, temples and 
residential suburbs was the difference between winning or losing WW2. At 
least with conventional bombing, bombers aim for specific military-related 
targets (like a barracks, munitions factory, depot etc). 

If the atomic bombs were dropped in the frontlines it wouldn't of been such 
a big issue. The regrettable aspects of the atomic bombings were that it 
was militarily unnecessary and used on civilians. Many Americans lack the 
sympathy because their country was the perpetrator and not the victim. If 
Nazi Germany used an atomic bomb on Boston, there is no doubt that 
Americans would condemn that act and call it a war crime - even if the 
Germans argued that "it saved lives". 

"Once it had been tested, President Truman faced the decision as to whether 
to use it. He did not like the idea, but he was persuaded that it would 
shorten the war against Japan and save American lives. It is my opinion 
that the use of this barbarous weapon at Hiroshima and Nagasaki was of no 
material assistance in our war against Japan. The Japanese were already 
defeated and ready to surrender because of the effective sea blockade and 
the successful bombing with conventional weapons... My own feeling was that 
in being the first to use it, we had adopted an ethical standard common to 
the barbarians of the Dark Ages. I was not taught to make wars in that 
fashion, and that wars cannot be won by destroying women and children." - 
Admiral William Leahy

top_comment.author: Neokiller333

comments.text:
+Neokiller333 No, there *is* nothing special about the neutron bomb; it's 
just a relatively small nuclear weapon. The various effects of a nuclear 
weapon scale differently with yield. Blast spreads out in a volume of air, 
so it decreases with the cube of distance. Thermal effects come from 
visible and infrared light, which follows an inverse square law. Gamma and 
neutron radiation are also subject to the inverse square law but they're 
also significantly absorbed by the atmosphere so there's an exponential 
factor as well.

This means that the deadly thermal and blast effects of large bombs reach 
well beyond the lethal range of their ionizing radiation, while those of 
small bombs do not. So the outer edge of the lethal region around a 
sufficiently small bomb will be determined by the range of its ionizing 
radiation, not its blast and thermal effects.

That said, there are design differences between different nuclear weapons 
of a given size. Different amounts and energies of neutrons are produced by 
fusion vs fission reactions,  and large "hydrogen" bombs actually produce 
much of their energy by fast fission of ordinary or depleted uranium that 
jackets the bomb by the fast neutrons from the fusion reactions. The 
neutron bomb omits this outer jacket both to reduce yield (thereby 
following the scaling laws above) and to let those fusion neutrons escape. 
So while it might produce more neutrons than a fission-only bomb of the 
same yield, a small fusion bomb would probably produce just as many.

There's nothing particularly special about neutron bombs. They're just

buildings alone is pretty fanciful.

comments.text:
+Isaiah Fowlkes Couple corrections. Little Boy was a uranium bomb which was 
detonated by way of an internal kinetic collision. Fatman was a plutonium 
based bomb which was detonated by an internal shaped charge of conventional 
explosives. Each detonated with an explosive yield of just over 10 kilotons 
(the exact values escape me at the moment). Modern hydrogen bombs, which 
operate through nuclear fusion (compared to the nuclear fission of earlier 
weapons) have explosive yields typically measured in megatons. (1 megaton = 
1000 kilotons = 1000000 tons of TNT) The most powerful of these detonated 
to date was the Russian Tsar Bomba, which exploded with a force of ~52 
megatons. It was detonated at only half the theoretical maximum yield for 
it's design, meaning if another bomb of the same make were to be built, it 
could have a maximum yield in the area of 100 megatons (equivalent to 
roughly 5000 Little Boys).

comments.text:
Those two statements are in no way analogous. The USA's foreign policy is 
in no way as blatant an act of war as a military bombing, and does not 
merit retaliation in the form of terrorism, as 9/11 did. I see the point 
you're attempting to make there, don't get me wrong, I understand that the 
casualties in Hiroshima were largely civilian and that does give credence 
to labeling it as an act of terror, but, quite frankly, you're just wrong. 
We were not already at war when 9/11 happened, we were mired in a 
gargantuan one when the bombings of Japan occurred. All IS fair in love and 
war, and if Japan didn't want to take serious injuries, they shouldn't have 
started it. The situations are far from synonymous, and the parallelism 
you're trying to set up between the incidents is ridiculous.
comments.author: Ron Burgundy

comments.text:
+Ron Burgundy
To that I say: Bomb a military installation during wartime, you're fighting 
a war. Bomb a civilian centre with an experimental device capable of having 
lasting and devastating effects, and you're a terrorist.

One of the codes of conduct in bombings is to drop fliers over civilian 
centres, warning people of the impending bombing, because the aim of a 
bombing is to destroy assets, not kill civilians. What occurred at 
Hiroshima was not war, nor was it tactics, it was terrorism. You might as 
well say to the victims of 9/11, "Hey, these are the repercussions of your 
country's foreign policy. Deal with it."

If the bomb had been dropped on a military base, I'd still have a problem 
with it, but I'd agree that it's the toils of war. But Hiroshima was a 
civilian centre filled with women and children, many of whom were sick of 
war. Not to mention the Japanese wanted to surrender; Churchill and Truman 
set the conditions such that the Japanese would refuse in order to continue 
the war. Part of it was so that Stalin wouldn't get a share of the spoils 
(the greed bastards), but also they wanted at least once to use the bomb 
they'd spent so much money on. It wasn't a matter of, "Oh, we must end this 
war. Counterattack for Pearl Harbour!" It was a matter of, "We spent all 
this money, let's use the bomb on school kids."
comments.author: Craig Cooper

comments.text:

Very simplistic way of looking at it. Using the bomb on Japan saved many 
lives on both sides, the fact is that Japan had been virtually flattened by 
conventional bombing already. A bomb is a bomb, you either do it one little 
bomb at a time or you use one big bomb and one plane, the end result is the 
same. The flip side of that is, that the Japanese had been attempting to 
surrender for months, they were trying to get the Soviets to help them gain 
terms from the Western Allies, but the Soviets were due to join the US in 
fighting against the Japanese at the end of August 1945, and knew if they 
had surrendered by then, that they (the Soviets) would loose out on a 
chance to grab some of the Japanese owned territories. Still think the 
western allies were right and justified in using the bomb.﻿

comments.text:
+Ghost Nappa It's easy to say all of this in hindsight. The reality is that 
all of the long term consequences were completely unexpected. When the bomb 
was initially developed they thought troops would be able to enter the area 
within minutes to sweep up. Had the full impact of nuclear weaponry been 
known at that time it's likely that it would have never been used in the 
first place.

Bear in mind that the Manhattan Project happened not long after a time when 
radiation was the new cure all fad and you could order pitchers through the 
mail that irradiated drinking water for "health benefits." By then they 
were starting to understand the dangers of radiation, but they had no idea 
it would stick around as long as it did. Their expectation was that it 
would dissipate faster than a bug bomb (those little cans you set off to 
kill off spiders, which only puts you out of the house for 2 hours or so), 
all of the damage, both from the explosion itself and through the 
radiation, would be delivered in an impulse, and the recovery process for 
those cities would be no different than if they would have been carpet 
bombed with conventional explosives.

Here's a scenario: Let's say you develop an engine that can allow a semi to 
go for 100 miles on a jug of peanut oil. No greenhouse emissions, you have 
an almost infinitely renewable resource, it's basically as clean as you can 
get short of mandating that all cars be propelled by sails. Yet it has the 
unexpected consequence of peanut allergy sufferers dropping by the hundreds 
from fatal allergic reactions to emissions that are otherwise harmless. 
It's guaranteed that the engine would be banned if no way can be devised to 
prevent the emission of the substance at the root of the problem, but 
should history remember you as a murderous barbarian because you didn't 
realize your engine would cause such problems?

And accusing Americans of incest? Are you serious? You do realize that 
incest occurs in all countries, don't you? In fact, for centuries your own 
country was run by people whose family trees often folded back in on 
themselves. That's right. The royalty and nobility of old Britannia were so 
intent on keeping their titles and lands in the family that they would 
often marry close cousins (i.e. their father's brother's daughter). It 
happened with such frequency that even the residents of Arkansas and 
Alabama, the USA's go-to states when people outside of Arkansas and Alabama 
want to make incest jokes, joke about the inbred royal family and noblemen.
comments.author: Possum Ridge Entertainment

top_comment.text:
You left out CASTLE BRAVO

That was probably the largest nuclear fallout accident in history.
It was the detonation of the first dry fuel mixture d-d or d-t fusion 
device in 1954 by the US. 

Before dry fuel the prospect of making Thermonuclear bombs, those which use 
nuclear fission to induce nuclear fusion was difficult as it required 
cryogenics.

The device was designed to have a yield of expected 6 megatons but 
detonated with a yield of 15+ megaton's because they only considered the 
Lithium-6 isotope of the lithium deuteride 'fusion fuel'. 

They assumed the Lithium-7 isotope was inert in the reaction, but it is 
not.  When 'struck'  by a neutron it's absorbed and Li-7 decay's to produce 
an alpha particle, and a tritium nuclei.  Tritium is what fuses with 
deuterium in the D-T fusion mechanism so the presence of Li-7 increased 
it's ratio drastically with deuterium and an incredibly larger quantity of 
energy was produced as a result. 

They should have separated the two isotopes especially since it was the 
secondary fusion fuel by default one would think, regardless of supply 
shortages at that time.

The result was that a populated island needed to be evacuated and are 
probably the most heavily irradiated in one dose group of unlucky 
individual's to live ... or die of cancer.

It was done on a non-ideal day and wind's carried the fallout large 
distance.  The USA has never detonated a nuclear weapon larger then this 
one ... probably because of this one. 

Tsar Bomba was the largest nuclear device to be detonated by the soviet's 
to have a 50 megaton yield.

To put it in perspective Hiroshima and Nagasaki were approximately 15-20 
kiloton yield, we are talking megatons here which is 1000 times greater 
then a kiloton.

So a divergence from the expected 6 megaton's to having it detonate with a 
15+ megaton yield that it did is the equivalent to 450 Hiroshima/Nagasaki 
scale bombs.  Most definitely the second biggest blunder in nuclear history 
(Chernobyl and the government's attempt's to cover it up when they really 
really needed to stop those reactor's from continuing fission but totally 
ignored so many simple things).

Feynmann was a very wise man.  Considering he discovered/invented the whole 
of Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) he has a deep and profound understanding 
of the spiritual or ... magical side of reality as well, which there are 
several fascinating discussions with him filmed, they're on youtube if you 
search.﻿

comments.text:
+vyor2
Yes their original design was to create a 100 megaton bomb ..... I wasn't 
going to repeat a textbook.  My already crazily long post was written to 
just throw out point form points because there is so much to this.

So ... what's your point? 

They scrapped the idea because a blast of that magnitude would thrust 
debris (and FF .... fission fragment ... fallout ...) extremely high, 
completely above the stratosphere AND the mesosphere into the 
thermosphere.  This is the region of our atmosphere where UV ionizing 
radiation occur's, thus it would turn the fallout into a vastly more deadly 
poison
and be in a region of space so high above ground that fallout would have 
been carried across the entire continent (west) and possibly even across 
the Atlantic Ocean onto North America ... that would have quite possibly 
started WW III right there.

The 50 megaton bomb itself had it's debris go way above our stratosphere 
and into the mesosphere.  As a consequence not only was the entire Kola 
Peninsula irradiated with fallout, but it was carried all the way across 
Scandanavia and almost reached Finland/Norway.

They PURPOSEFULLY used a LEAD tamper in the third stage, whereas typically 
a U-238 tamper is used because it amplifies the X-ray's produced by the 
secondary (and partially the primary) which is being directed into the now 
fusing (after detonation) nuclei of the third stage fuel (the fusion fuel) 
to significantly increase the amount of fuel which undergoes nuclear 
fusion, which in turn increases the amount of U-235 that fission's (he says 
in this video that only 1.3% of the fission bomb is actually .... 
fissioned).  The entire point of the fusion stage is to increase fissioning 
of the primary, the heat/power/shockwave does NOT come from nuclear fusion, 
it comes from the amplified U-235 nuclear fission of the primary due to the 
energy and fast neutrons that the tertiary nuclear fusion event generates.

It's not about megaton's anyways, it's about mass/yield (mass of the bomb 
to it's yield).  The Tsar Bomba was 27 metric tonnes (27,000 kg ... which 
is ... i dont know and hate imperial system so we'll just go with the good 
old multiply by 2.2 which is about 60,000 pounds).

It was a TEST shot and there were never any plans of creating nuclear 
weapons in that high of a megaton range for military usage BEFORE or after 
the Tsar Bomba detonation.  Why?

MIRVS.  A single Trident II missile can carry a warhead that has 8-12 
nuclear bomb's on them (MIRV = Multiple Independently Targatable Reentry 
vehicle(s)).  ONE single ICBM can carpet blanket a country with many 
nuclear warheads off the same missile.  So much of a scare that UN measures 
have made it so that Trident II ICBMs can only carry 4 MIRVs ('legally') on 
them ... which to me still sounds like a pointless resolution, 1 bomb is 
bad enough, 4 is ... well disgusting.

Do you know the yield that the US designates it's W88/W89 warhead's?  Only 
200 kiloton's (it can be 'dialed' down or up to I think 600 kiloton's).

Consider too that US has 17 ohio class sub's with 24 of these missiles 
each, overkill just a bit.

Megaton scale nuclear warheads are impractical for the mass/yield ratio, 
eg. a W89 warhead is only 1 meter long and only weighs 150kg .... vs. Tsar 
Bomba @ 27,000kg and the W89 still has a yield of 200 kiloton's and 
obviously small enough to be fitted on a MIRVed ICBM.  Can you not see the 
VASTLY increased yield per kg that smaller weapons have).

There's a second reason why megaton scale bombs are impractical and most 
test shot's by the soviet's were never in that range (most were in fact 
only baby nukes in the 20 kiloton range because they were TESTS to make 
better fuel, design and advanced accidental detonation prevention 
mechanisms).

That second reason is that a megaton scale shot creates a crater so deep 
that the shockwave the bomb creates reflects BACK into the crater vs. 
spreading outwards and obliterating everything in it's path.

I could go on for HOUR's, but you see now why I started stating brief 
points of note because my msg was as epically long as this one which I 
doubt anyone will read (though you'd be wise to know what your Military has 
in it's hands).

top_comment.text:
For the record, Japan surrendered in WW2 because Russia entered the war 
against them in Manchuria.  This left Japan faced with two invading armies 
from different directions, and removed the final diplomatic option of 
having Stalin negotiate conditional peace to keep their way of life (and 
emperor.)  The firebombing of 67 cities previous to the atomic bombs, most 
more than 50% destroyed, did nothing to persuade Japan to surrender and 2 
more were barely noteworthy.﻿

comments.text:
+TheVoiceOfReason
 Stalin was hauling mass troops and equipment straight down to southern 
Korea.

Japan would have been flanked by Stalin from the west and from the Allies 
from the East.

Stalin attacked Manchuria on Aug. 9, the same day that the Soviet-Japan 
treaty of non-aggression expired.

I don't think the nuclear bombs were what forced Japan to surrender (gave 
them a damned good punch in the face though) but rather that Russia 
declared war on Japan that day and had a clear path all the way down Korea 
(which lies west of Japan) and the Allies had the eastern front of islands 
secured.  They would have crushed Japan like a tin can, regardless of how 
it's people 'rose up'.

Japan didn't even call a session when the first bomb was dropped, it didn't 
scare them and they ignored it didn't even have military leader's convene 
to discuss this incredible weapon that man (except Trinity) had not ever 
seen before.

That's why the Korean war happened too, US did not like soviets spreading 
communism south so invented a border (38th parallel) :) 

There was once only one Korea.

comments.text:
+TheVoiceOfReason
Since nobody has mentioned it, the plan was called Operation Downfall which 
was split into two fronts, Operation Olympic and Operation Coronet.

There has been many studies done on what MIGHT HAVE HAPPENED!!!!

The only conclusion you can make is that there would have been a much 
larger number of dead Japanese and Allied forces if RUSSIA DID NOT INVADE 
MANCHURIA on the same day the second atomic bomb was dropped (Aug. 9).

AKA i'm saying the nuclear bombs didn't end the war, the treaty of 
non-aggression between Russia and Japan that expired on Aug. 9 after which 
Russia immediately attacked Japan from their vulnerable North and Western 
front's was what likely forced Emperor Hirohito to capitulate and surrender.
comments.author: MDMA4LIFE

comments.text:
+TheVoiceOfReason Exactly. They didn't surrender, even after many more 
people died in fire-bombing than the atom bomb. That completely proves my 
point: that using the atom bomb to kill people was pointless, it was it's 
devastating power that persuaded the emperor to surrender, not the death 
toll. So, once again, why was it dropped on a city and not an island.

You're arguing from an emotive stance which suppprts a 'you guys are evil 
so we should kill as many of you as possible' argument, but is in no way a 
moral argument.

And it shouldn't matter where I'm from (I'm English, by the way. Two weeks 
from destruction by the Nazis . . .) and what I've experienced; nothing 
justifies nuking people. It's senseless, clumsy and total destruction which 
serves no other purpose than to intimidate and annihilate. Frankly I think 
it is beneath a human to enact such an event.

As I've said before, nuclear weapons ended the war and I would have used 
them if I had to decide, but I would not have (immediately) dropped them on 
population centres. I would have exhausted every possibility before doing 
so. Your point about death not being an effective way to break resolve 
shows why . . .
comments.author: Jonathan Westoby

comments.text:
How do you know they wouldn't have surrendered if they appreciated the full 
devastating capacity of atomic warfare? How did killing hundreds of 
thousands 'totally' defeat a nation of millions? Wasn't defeat ultimately 
chosen by the Emperor, therefore meaning that the only mind we had to 
conquer was his? Wouldn't a demonstration of atomic power have achieved 
that whether it was dropped on people or not?

And you are right about the disgraceful treatment of civilians and POWs by 
the Imperial army, but isn't that a case for the courts and rule of law, 
not indiscriminate and vengeful destruction. That's disgraceful itself. And 
speaking of disgrace: the Japanese saw prisoners as 'less than human' 
because they had surrendered rather than die fighting, something the 
Japanese culture at the time found abhorrent. How does that legitimise 
killing civilians? Because their nation hadn't surrendered, so they 
deserved to die in droves, like wiping out insects? Retribution should have 
been meted out to those responsible, they way we punish conscious human 
beings responsible for their own actions . . .
comments.author: Jonathan Westoby

comments.text:
The cost in American and Allied lives in flushing out every last Jap from 
every booby-trapped hole would have been phenomenal. The Japanese would not 
have surrendered any other way. You could argue that their culture has 
changed now, but at that time they saw the Allies as being less than human, 
proven by their disgraceful treatment of allied POWs. As a country they had 
to be defeated, totally.
comments.author: Manic Elf

comments.text:
+Jonathan Westoby Here's the thing:  The bombs were intimidating BECAUSE 
they hit two cities.  If some bomb just got dropped on a small island, not 
many would've died and it would've just been "another bomb".  Dropping them 
on the cities allowed the Japanese to see what the real deal was.  Even so, 
it took 2 bombs and a Soviet invasion of Manchuria to have the Japanese 
surrender.
comments.author: ajbenius

comments.text:
Yep, that seemed to be the case, and an invasion would have been a bloody 
mess. The bombs ended the war; and even then the Emperor had to overrule 
the chief of staff, who wanted to pursue it. But my point still stands. Why 
didn't they try to call their bluff? Why bomb two cities?

We'll never know if dropping the atom bomb on people (the only time it's 
been done) was the only solution, because they never tried any 
alternatives. There was no mitigation, no self-control. The Japanese were 
so bloody-minded they made the Nazis look like boy-scouts, so the Americans 
nuked them, in a seeming 'two wrongs make a right' moment.
comments.author: Jonathan Westoby

comments.text:
The atom bomb wasn't a strategic strike; it's purpose was not to weaken a 
tactical position or disrupt production, its purpose was to destroy and 
intimidate. Blow up an island or two, then threaten to take the same 
destruction to the mainland.

If the Japanese knew what was coming who knows how many deaths could have 
been avoided. It's not certain that they would have surrendered, but the 
'surprise! Deal with that!' Obliteration of two cities was a dick move in 
anyone's book. Morally speaking, of course.

It all stemmed from a morbid curiosity about the effects of this new weapon 
on human beings. That's a dark mind-set right there . . .
comments.author: Jonathan Westoby

Chinese still hate eachother. The Japanese held contests to see who could

Had America been foreced to make landfall on Japan, our relations might be

comments.author: Mike Zilla

comments.text:
+TheVoiceOfReason True. More damage was caused in the fire-bombing of 
Dresden AFTER the war had ended than the atomic bombs in Japan; both were 
disgusting  things to do. However, there is something particularly horrific 
in the instantaneously efficient and extended radiation poisoning of the 
atomic attack.
At that moment we had achieved, as a species, the unlocking of a truth 
about our universe first postulated by Leucippus, but beyond his wildest 
imaginings; and we used it to eviscerate in minutes whole generations of 
human beings.
Splitting an atom reveals one of the most startlingly beautiful 
compositions in our universe, which makes our ugly use of it 
proportionately venal. 
War kills people, and fire can warm or burn; bombs are designed with one 
thing in mind -- death, but the moral leap we take in wielding atomic 
energy, the inner energy of the universe, in the cause of death and 
destruction is, I personally believe, a new chapter in our moral 
responsibility as a species.
comments.author: Jonathan Westoby

The Russian thing won't 'hit the fan' in a way that will cause nuclear 
devastation. It's extremely unlikely that nuclear warfare will occur 
anytime soon. Nuclear Terrorism is possible, but highly unlikely (and the 
only reason that's even possible is because it's nuclear /terrorism/, not 
nuclear war). The next time nuclear war occurs, it will probably be during 
circumstances where mutual destruction is a non-issue. For example, if we 
develop a reliable way to shoot down nukes, nuclear war becomes more 
reasonable. Most likely, the next nuclear war will occur once people have 
started to colonize other worlds.

top_comment.text:
K, either "cruel bombs" or a "cruel invasions". An invasion of Japan would 
cause even more death and destruction and prolong the war to possibly even 
the 1950s. 

Also, the Japanese I400 and I401 aircraft carrier submarines were on their 
way to not Hawaii, but California. On the same day an invasion of Japan 
would have taken place, Japanese light bombers would be burning down cities 
like San Fransisco, San Diego, maybe even as far as Las Vegas.

This would have angered the United States even more, and would possibly 
open a new front, a second Pearl Harbor.

The United States being distracted with Japan would allow North Korea to 
completely invade South Korea, which would make North Korea an actual 
threat in modern day.

The prolonged war would lead to even more development of weapons, and might 
even prolong WW2 into a possible conflict with the Soviets.

We would ask for help, they would bring up their heavy losses against the 
Germans. We would send supplies, they would get the wrong idea (note that 
this actually happened) 
They would be outraged as they were at the conference about invading Japan 
from the north and ending WW2. 

U.S, U.K, Canadian, Australian, Mexican, and all other allies in Japanese 
POW camps would have to endear a lot more years of abuse. 

Overall, its worth the H bombs...
﻿

top_comment.author: HylianMattress

comments.text:
Recreate stars?
You're not talking about nuclear fission (splitting of atoms) right? 
Because that's the polar opposite of how stars work, and on an incredibly 
small scale. Stars work on the principle of nuclear fusion (melding of 
atoms), and even then it's on a massive scale and continuous. Not to 
mention that viable nuclear fusion hasn't been invented. It takes an 
incredible amount of power to trigger a nuclear fusion reaction. Hydrogen 
bombs for example use a nuclear fission reaction (exploding a regular 
nuclear bomb) in order to start the nuclear fusion.

+Tastypie(•̀ᴗ•́)و ̑ I would like to point out that, a remote detonation of 
the bomb would still result in casaulties if it were within the japanese 
peoples visible range. most of the deaths caused by the bombs weren't in 
the initial explosion, but the nuclear fallout caused by the explosion. 
Hence why we call nukes "dirty bombs."

sending japan footage from the manhattan project would probably be the best 
safe scare tactic we could do. after receiving the footage, give the 
Emperor two weeks to mull it over, or be hit by a bomb. simple.

the scary part about nukes isn't just the explosive destructive power they 
create, it is mostly the radioactive fallout caused by the bombs, and at 
the time, nobody knew the bombs created so much radiation (or so they 
claimed) and since japan had no idea about how the bombs worked and had no 
idea that it created radiation. they had no way of knowing how to 
immediately treat its populace when they came in sick with radiation 
sickness. people have known what radiation sickness was and how to treat it 
properly (to some degree) in the 1940's but the fact of having people come 
in to see doctors, numbering in the 100,000. nobody could tell, and they 
certainly didn't think it was radiation sickness until they tried treating 
it as radiation sickness. radiation sickness was only reported when miners 
and other people dealing with radioactive elements were exposed, very small 
numbers of people. the sickness was never found in such a large number 
until nukes were developed.

In any case, leaflets alone won't intimidate the opponent. But a detonating 
a-bomb would. Just not on populated ground.

I give you an example. You see how your child plays with a lighter. You 
tell the child that this is dangerous and that it shouldn't do it 
(leaflets).
But the child continues playing with the lighter. As punishment, you decide 
to put the child's hand on a hot plate for 1 minute (a-bomb). The child 
suffers from a 3rd degree burn. Alternatively, you could have taken the 
childs finger and put it on the hot plate for 1 second to make your point 
clear (dropping of the bomb next to a city).

like reading all the comments. At the time the U.S wasn't trying to get 
involved in the war they were just supplying weapons and supplies. Hitler

wouldn't have been enough, they would've just kept fighting because they're

that the emperor was not a god but a regular person and so did he. If the

motivation was what they saw as a god but they had that no more there for 
they had no reason to fight.

top_comment.text:
The scientist that have created these weapons often find themselves 
disgusted by what their invention was used for. These are the pioneers of 
many of the things we use in the modern day, the golden age of physics. 
Wernher Von Braun worked for the Nazis during WWII developing the V2 
rocket. The rocket stood more than 40 feet high, over 56,000 pounds of 
thrust, and a velocity of 3,600 miles an hour. When the first of these 
rockets hit Britain he stated "The rocket performed perfectly, it just 
landed on the wrong planet". Those rockets would be used later in the 
creation of the rockets that took Americans into space. The scientist that 
worked so hard in the Manhattan project, developed the atom bomb. They knew 
what minute reactions would occur but, had no idea what the major 
consequences would be. They had no idea what the bomb would do when 
detonated. Some scientist feared that the bomb would destroy the earth, set 
the atmosphere on fire, or do nothing at all. After seeing the completion 
of his work and witnessing the detonation of his device; Robert Oppenheimer 
stated "I have become death, the destroyer of worlds". These are not often 
evil men, or mad scientist. They are chasing creation and discovery and 
often see their work used to decimate life instead of bettering humanity. ﻿

comments.text:
+winstonIpresume You should learn the difference between a fact and an 
opinion.

CO2 has strong resonances in the far IR around 10 microns. Therefore it's a 
greenhouse gas. That's a simple, indisputable fact. Same for H2O, N2O, CH4 
and some others.

Saying that CO2 must be benign because it's involved in plant respiration 
is simply bizarre. H2O is even more essential to life. Does that make 
floods and tsunamis  a good thing?

Global warming due to human fossil fuel CO2 emissions is another 
established fact. But mitigating it has nothing to do with "saving the 
planet". The earth is extremely old and has already seen much worse from 
other, natural causes.

But those extremes happened long before us humans, and life would have been 
a lot harder -- or impossible. Stopping AGW isn't about saving the earth, 
it's about saving our ability to live on it. Does that appeal more to you?

Now if you don't give a fuck about subsequent generations, or about poor 
countries stupid enough to live near sea level, that's an opinion so you're 
entitled to it. But AGW itself is a fact, and you would really do well to 
learn the distinction between opinions and facts.
comments.author: ApolloWasReal

comments.text:
+ApolloWasReal I agree entirely. All of our commercial reactors are light 
water reactors and that design dates back to the 1940s. It was chosen for 
military reasons at the time and became the standard not because it was the 
best design but because it was the first to be widely adopted. Nuclear 
power plants are very expensive to build and costly to maintain which made 
the industry disinterested in experimenting with other reactor designs, of 
which there were many even in the 1950s. 

Almost all of the problems with our nuclear power industry can or have been 
solved already elsewhere and remain unfixed for political reasons. It is my 
opinion that global warming is a threat so much greater than nuclear waste 
that we should make nuclear the main share of our base load power supply 
while aggressively switching to renewables. 

Switching to nuclear might be kicking a can down the road but staying on 
fossil fuels is like kicking the can down a mountainside of loose rocks. 
Neither is good but one we can control, the other might start something we 
can't stop.
comments.author: Galen Matson

comments.text:
+Michael Moore Nuclear waste is a purely political problem, the technical 
problems were solved long ago. And it would be even less of a problem if we 
were to replace our current aging power reactors with much more efficient 
fast neutron reactors that burn all the plutonium and other actinides they 
produce, leaving only fission products in the waste. They decay so much 
more quickly that within just a few hundred years the radioactivity of the 
waste is back down to the level of the uranium ore it came from.

Current reactor waste is so long lived only because it contains so much 
unburned fuel. In fact, the Canadians already have reactors capable of 
burning our "waste" as their fuel. Again, the problems are political, not 
technical.
comments.author: ApolloWasReal

comments.text:
+John Mullan Die in combat as opposed to quick death by incineration or 
slow death from radiation sickness and starvation? Perhaps. Seems like a 
false dichotomy.

I actually agree with most of what you've said. Yet I still believe we 
would be better off without nuclear weapons. Conventional bombings during 
WW2 killed more people than Nagasaki or Hiroshima but with improvement of 
devices into megaton yields nuclear weapons now eclipse conventional 
weapons by such a margin that our species could not survive a nuclear war.

So yes, if it meant more conventional wars I still believe it would be 
better for our long term survival. Also, how many nuclear weapons are 
required for effective deterrence? At the peak of the Cold War the Soviet 
Union had over 45,000 nuclear weapons. Russia still has over 8000 and we 
have over 7000. I don't support unilateral disarmament but if deterrence is 
the goal then we should pursue further bilateral reductions with Russia.

top_comment.text:
A nuclear warhead won't go off if you drop it. Similarly to a hunk of C4 
(which needs a detonator cap to be anything more than Playdough), nuclear 
weapons are nothing but radioactive paperweights unless they are armed 
(with the proper codes). Even then, they have to be programmed to detonate 
upon impact. But since most nuclear weapons are set to explode above 
ground, not upon impact, even an armed nuke would be very unlikely to 
detonate if dropped or set aflame.﻿

comments.text:
If Earth were to impact such an object, everything here would have 
basically no chance of surviving. Even if we were hit by a "planet" 
matching the moon in size and density at the shallowest angle and the 
lowest speed possible, the impact could increase Earth's day-length by 16 
hours or slow it down by about 8. This is happening at the speed of sound 
in the ground, but the impactor is moving much faster, meaning that there 
would be a wavefront on the ground where suddenly it is moving several 
hundred miles per hour faster or slower. This rippling makes online 
asteroid-impact-calculators understate the effect of the Earthquake 
dramtically. The calculators say that on not-quite the opposite side of the 
world (to avoid the deadly reverberating effects of the antipode of the 
explosion) one would first feel the siesmic shaking and that it would 
"only" be enough to destroy sturdy buildings and throw the water out of 
lakes. This is not true. In reality, the suborbital debris and air blast 
would outrace the Earthquake. The pressure from the airblast would be on 
the order of 500 atmospheres, in other words, being hit by air at that 
speed would feel like having a white-hot train thrown at you at the speed 
of sound... Even if you were in orbit, you would probably be hit by the 
bulging atmosphere. If you managed to survive, say, by being in a bunker 
the likes of which the world has never seen, you would have to contend with 
immense changes in the Earth. One major change would be that the continents 
may be re-sculpted completely and that Earth would heat up... a lot. If the 
heat were evenly distributed throughout the Earth, each kilogram would 
recieve about 670,000 joules. This would be enough to raise the temperature 
of the entire thing by about 800 degrees Celsius, enough to melt aluminum, 
lead, tin, zinc, magnesium, and most rocks. The Earth would literally BE 
lava after the impact.

Of course, if earth were to be hit by another Earth, it would be a very 
birght explosion that would slowly condense back into a new planet or 
perhaps not even do that. The impact speed would approach 16000 m/s, at the 
minimum end. NOBODY would be safe. The explosion would be on the order of 
8E32 joules. If it took  1000 seconds to release the energy, during that 
thousand seconds, Earth (Or Earth and the other planet) would be 2000 times 
brighter than the sun at the same distance. The moon would receive enough 
heat to shatter or boil much of its surface into space and melt the rest. 
Astronauts on Mars who could see the collision would be vaporized within 
only a few seconds. The explosion would be brighter than an atomic bomb at 
3 km, but last for over half an hour.
So yeah, planets colliding wouldn't just kill everyone and everything on 
them and in them and in orbit, it would leave scars on other celestial 
bodies as well and kill everyone within line-of-site even on other planets.
comments.author: Peter Smythe

comments.text:
+tubefan90000
The NPT powers know who have nuclear weapons. It's not like someone could 
just make one in their backyard. The resources needed to make them are 
carefully monitored. Special plants need to be constructed to get the right 
type of payload. You've seen Iran building secretive nuclear plants which 
screamed weaponized payloads. They tried to hide it, but it was discovered.

And actually, the strongest single payload was dropped as a test in 1961 by 
the USSR. It was 50 MT. Current warheads are weaker, but more easily 
deployed. But, that actually helps prevent their use. If the US or Russia 
ever decided to use even one, they would be met with a overwhelming for by 
the other. MAD has done a good job at preventing the use of nuclear weapons.

The point is that it doesn't matter how powerful they are. What matters is 
that more than one nation has the power to keep the other in line. It's 
been ~70 years and there hasn't been a single nuclear war..
comments.author: Aeghamedic

comments.text:

actually more just pointing out possibilities than claiming it to be true, 
I find that kind of thing fun sometimes), they are much more powerful than 
before.
comments.author: tubefan90000

comments.text:
+tubefan90000
There really aren't ways around it without being extremely suspicious. And 
there's no real reason to lie. It's not the number of nukes that's the 
threat. Ten or ten thousand, the damage will be done all the same. There 
are more warheads available than metropolitan areas.

France, the UK, China, Pakistan, India, Israel, and North Korea have fewer 
total warheads than the US has active. The two powers which need to, and 
have, reduce their stockpile would be the signers, the US and Russia.

And there's also the Test Ban treaty which limits the production of new 
warheads.

comments.text:

Nuclear weapons aren't like conventional weaponry. They've only been used 
twice in war, and that was their first use. People are afraid of them being 
used. So it's within everyone's interest to be upfront about how many they 
have and where they are.

top_comment.text:
Fire, Miss-communication, Rouge Officers, and Dropping have extremely small 
chances of nuclear detonation. Fire, cannot set off a warhead nor the 
explosives used to detonate the nuclear charge. Miss-communication, only if 
you are talking about there being a glitch in the programming of the bomb 
itself somehow. Way to many checks and balances in place in the Military 
for that to happen. Rouge Officer... not possible; you need a minimum of 
two people to even start the launch computer and a set of no less than 5 
separate codes to begin the launch sequence. Dropping... please. You can 
put a pneumatic jack-hammer directly to the Uranium or Plutonium core and 
it still wouldn't go off. Little Boy was Uranium 235... not Plutonium. 
Atomic Bombs... use Uranium. NUCLEAR bombs, generally use Plutonium.

Vsauce's comment about the B52 crashing even proves my point... NO NUCLEAR 
BOMBER CREW carries said bombs with their detonation devices inside the 
bomb... these devices are only installed once the bomber is over the target 
bomb release point. You can crash these things strapped to an airplane and 
smash them into the ground at 600 miles per hour from 50,000 feet... and 
STILL NO NUCLEAR EXPLOSION. WHY???

Because to DETONATE a Nuclear or Atomic explosive, you must create a 
critical mass within 1, 1 trillionth of a second. And the way to do this, 
is by either smashing one piece of uranium into another at the several 
hundred times the speed of sound (Little Boy Design) or by detonating 
several high explosive charges around a solid core of Plutonium or Uranium 
in an exact detonation sequence that must be timed to the nanosecond and 
has a timing error of 3 nanoseconds + or - of the previous and next 
explosion in  the sequence (Fat Man)﻿

"Cruel bombs" were not used for cruel purposes.

Quite a few people like +Rinku - The Hero of Time  and other commenters 
bellow have stated how the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear bombings are 
cruel, disgusting, twisted.

But here is a message that was forgotten to history.

The Americans have had many bombers fly over Japan months before the 2 
'cruel bombs' droped. But these are not bombers throwing hate. No bombs 
were dropped by them. But only a message. a Leaflet. Warning the Japanese 
citizens to evacuate, leave. The Americans are not as cruel and heartless 
as history makes them out to be.
Because these men have risked there lives flying over a hostile aerospace 
that was one of the most dangerous places to fly in the world at the time, 
Where people would kill them self for there country and kill you in the 
process. 

These people have went through extreme lengths to leave this message, to 
warn the Japanese citizens and the country as a whole of what was coming on 
August 1945.
Warning them of the 30 targets that they should avoid and the fact that 
THEY are not the target.

But the majority... did not take the warning seriously... they decided to 
stay instead.

These bombs may be cruel, but they were not used for a cruel purpose. 


Copy of the Note: "

*TO THE JAPANESE PEOPLE:*
America asks that you take immediate heed of what we say on this leaflet.

We are in possession of the most destructive explosive ever devised by man. 
A single one of our newly developed atomic bombs is actually the equivalent 
in explosive power to what 2000 of our giant B-29s can carry on a single 
mission. This awful fact is one for you to ponder and we solemnly assure 
you it is grimly accurate.

We have just begun to use this weapon against your homeland. If you still 
have any doubt, make inquiry as to what happened to Hiroshima when just one 
atomic bomb fell on that city.

Before using this bomb to destroy every resource of the military by which 
they are prolonging this useless war, we ask that you now petition the 
Emperor to end the war. Our president has outlined for you the thirteen 
consequences of an honorable surrender. We urge that you accept these 
consequences and begin the work of building a new, better and peace-loving 
Japan.

You should take steps now to cease military resistance. Otherwise, we shall 
resolutely employ this bomb and all our other superior weapons to promptly 
and forcefully end the war.

*EVACUATE YOUR CITIES.*


And the second leaflet dropped by the americans after the first 'cruel 
bomb'.

"*ATTENTION JAPANESE PEOPLE. EVACUATE YOUR CITIES.*
Because your military leaders have rejected the thirteen part surrender 
declaration, two momentous events have occurred in the last few days.

The Soviet Union, because of this rejection on the part of the military has 
notified your Ambassador Sato that it has declared war on your nation. 
Thus, all powerful countries of the world are now at war with you.

Also, because of your leaders' refusal to accept the surrender declaration 
that would enable Japan to honorably end this useless war, we have employed

A single one of our newly developed atomic bombs is actually the equivalent

comments.text:
+Crunsher
My understanding is that no one was aware of the radiation hazard that they 
posed (I'm sure Truman and the military at large was unaware but perhaps 
the scientists and those working closely with them knew).  Either way, 
debating the dropping of the bombs and whether or not it's a good thing 
that the US developed it, is, in my opinion a dumb debate.  Without doubt 
this was a positive thing because even though it killed many many people 
and many more in horrible ways, ultimately it did save lives (both American 
*and* Japanese--and probably saved more Japanese lives than American).

The takeaway from this horrible experiment is that we should do our best to 
never use another one in war.  It's hard to imagine a scenario today that 
would warrant their use.  MAD, during the cold war was an insane policy and 
probably was nothing more than a game of chicken (thank god nobody every 
flinched--or did we *both* flinch with the game of chicken metaphor?).  The 
goal should be to destroy all nuclear weapons, but this just isn't 
practical in today's global environment.  70 years after WWII and the US is 
still playing the role of peace keeper and frankly, I think a very 
necessary role *(even though we screw it up a lot of the times)*.


p.s. To anyone who might say, OK, drop one, but why a second three days 
later?  This is actually because we threatened to drop several if they 
didn't surrender but the fact was that we could not actually make enough to 
follow through with this threat (in fact the Hiroshima bomb, I believe, had 
never even been tested because it was so hard to enrich enough 
Uranium-235).  By dropping another so quickly, we bluffed the Japanese into 
thinking we were very capable of doing such a thing.  Luckily they didn't 
call our bluff (although the military wanted to).  So the second bomb was 
just as necessary as the first to make the Japanese believe we were serious.
comments.author: Jared B

comments.text:
Wow, talk about some pretty steep assumptions in the replies. Wolph didn't 
even specify WHICH God he might have been talking about; he didn't even 
specify if he meant a deity, or just the concept of what God is. The 
concept of a being who is omnipotent, omnipresent, and omniscience; there's 
some other traits sometimes applied, but that generally covers the most 
basic definition in most cases, so I'm doing a bit of bracketing here about 
those other possible definitions (omnibenevolence for instance).

A being that is all powerful, all present, and all knowing. In this sense, 
if you forgo the other assumptions that can be made by what he means by the 
word 'god', his statement is not so untrue. Science does attempt and even 
succeed in some cases to give these things. Something as simple as a 
security camera system allows a certain amount of omnipresence, for example.

Now, if you wanted to levy a complaint against this statement, it wouldn't 
be that these two concepts (science and god) are incompatible, but that the 
statement is so vague and expansive that it becomes meaningless. What 
meaning you take away from it is your own, rather then actually belonging 
to the quote. This isn't necessarily bad, but it can be irksome for those 
who want a meaning defined by the writer.
comments.author: Akago

comments.text:
Before you go off preaching on about the atrocities of America, take into 
account the ones performed by the Japanese during the same war. At the 
time, the Japanese military did not believe in the notion of surrender, and 
as such did not tolerate those who did. When they invaded China, they 
killed thousands of Chinese soldiers that had tried to surrender. 
Afterwards, they set their sights on civilians. There were reports that 
Japanese soldiers would throw Chinese babies into the air then catch them 
with their bayonets. When Japan invaded the Philippeans, there were 
hundreds of thousands of American and Filipino soldiers whom surrendered as 
well as displaced civilians. The Japanese solution was the Bataan death 
march, an 80 mile march without any break or rest, where any wounded or 
stragglers were shot and killed. The destination, The former U.S. Base of 
Camp O'Donnel, was another hell, not much different than Nazi Concentration 
camps. Many of the men who entered, never came out. Some where tortured to 
death, others shot, and others starved.

It is because of this intolerance of surrender and the Japanese ideal of 
absolute war, the complete destruction of an enemy, that the decision to 
drop the bomb was made. It was estimated that it would cost the lives of 
nearly a million soldiers in order to successfully invade and occupy Japan 
and the surrounding isles. The Japanese people were brainwashed into 
believing that we were coming to destroy them all as a people. Civilians 
would have fought back in any way they could, forcing confrontations. It 
was with that in mind that the bomb was dropped. Was it Ethical? No, but 
that is the nature of war. Was it the best decision? That is a matter of 
perspective and debate. But it is what happened, regardless of who you 
blame. Keep in mind, that during war, neither side is innocent. Each is 
guilty of their own atrocities. Because war unto itself is a crime against 
humanity.
comments.author: XxXGunMonkeyXxX

comments.author: ForgottenSouI

comments.text:
+ForgottenSouI U-235 (and Pu-239, and U-233) can fission in *many* more 
ways than Kr and Ba so we can only state statistics. Fission is most likely 
to occur into two unequal masses with mass numbers 95 and 135, but 
sometimes it can even split into *three* pieces. So nuclear waste consists 
of an extremely large range of isotopes with half-lives ranging from 
milliseconds to millions of years, with some actually being stable 
(non-radioactive), and as they decay and/or absorb neutrons in the reactor 
even more isotopes are produced.
comments.author: ApolloWasReal

comments.text:
+oisiaa you are correct that 1.38% if the 64 kg fissioned, but what Vsauce 
meant was that 2/3 g, or 0.7g of mass was converted into pure energy.

When an Uranium atom goes under fission, not it's entire mass is converted 
into energy, instead it is split into 2 larger parts, Kr and Ba and 
(usually) 3 more neutrons.
The interesting part is that when you weight the Kr, Ba and the neutrons, 
they will actually be slightly lighter than the original Uranium atom.
This very tiny difference in mass is what has converted into pure energy. 
That's where the 0.7g comes from.


But why is this? you might ask
You have to think about how an atom holds itself together. It is obviously 
not gravity, since gravity is so weak, or electrostatic forces, since + 
repels from +  and the nucleus is filled with protons. So by common sense, 
the atom shouldn't even be able to hold itself together.
But the atom actually transforms some of it's own mass into energy to 
"glue" itself together. Obviously, the Uranium atom is much much bigger 
than Kr and Ba, so the Uranium atom transforms much more mass into "glue" 
than Kr or Ba.
Since Kr and Ba transform less of it's own mass into energy compared to 
Uranium, the excess "glue" that held the Uranium atom together has nowhere 
else to go since Kr and Ba already has enough "glue", so it is turned into 
pure energy.
That excess "glue" is where the atomic bomb gets its destructive energy, 
and the amount of "glue" that was converted in the bomb is soo small that 
it only amounts to 0.7g.
comments.author: ForgottenSouI

comments.text:
That 0.7 grams is just the amount of matter turned into energy by E=mc^2. 
Only some of the mass of the uranium that fissioned was turned into energy; 
the rest remained in the mass of the fission products and neutrons.

By comparison, a typical large nuclear power plant produces 1 gigawatt of 
electricity at about 1/3 efficiency. It therefore turns about 1 kg of 
matter into energy each year.
comments.author: ApolloWasReal

comments.text:
Let's do the math, shall we?
E=mc^2
E=.0007kg x 299,792,458^2 m/s
E=.0007kg x 8.987 X10^16 m^2/s^2
E= 62,910,000,000,000 Joules (kg m^2/s^2)

We know that Little Boy had about a 16 kiloton yield, which is equal to 
roughly  66,940,000,000,000 Joules (4.184 gigajoules per ton).

Looks like the math is pretty close.

comments.text:
The Soviets and most of Eastern Europe faced a war of extermination by the 
Germans. North Africa today is still plagued by landmines placed over 
seventy years ago by both Britain, and Germany. The Chinese were raped and 
destroyed by the Japanese out of hate. The Soviets razed Germany to the 
ground out of hate for destroying their homeland. The British firebombed 
and burned many German cities to the ground to ruin morale. The Americans 
were assaulted for stopping the Japanese Empire's advances in the far east, 
and the Japanese were firebombed and blasted into oblivion.

Six million people were killed in cold blood out of racism and 
superstition. Millions more were killed for simply being in the wrong place 
at the wrong time. An entire race of people was interred out of fear, 
stolen from their homes. An entire generation was practically lost around 
the world for political interests. Even then, thousands in the end were 
traded between the English and Soviets in good ol' fashioned imperialism.

Near 50% of the world was engaged in pitched combat, across all continents, 
and almost everyone felt its influence. War is not a pleasant affair, and 
unless you've got the stomach for it, I suggest you have nothing to do with 
it.

Dude, not to be a party pooper but if they didnt drop the bomb, millions of

of Americans would die and the war would have lasted more years. Japan

have died or woulds have no parents. It didnt matter what United Stated

comments.text:
+Ali Alshakhs Every nation in the war had begun targeting civilians long 
before the US ever got involved. Go research firebombing, and you'll 
realize that in many cases, firebombed cities had more dead civilians than 
either Hiroshima or Nagasaki. Firebombing would have been the rule had the 
US gone ahead with a conventional invasion(in fact it already was for every 
side).

Plus, even after the nukes, most Japanese leaders were still planning to 
fight. It took a direct intervention from the emperor to stop the madness. 

I encourage you to research things like this before jumping to conclusions 
and assuming you could have done any differently in the same situation. 
Vision is always 20/20 in hindsight, and I can guarantee you wouldn't have 
done any better in the same position with the same knowledge possessed by 
the US.

comments.text:
We people fight about whether or not they should've used the nukes or not, 
when nukes should not have existed in the first place. Hell even bombs are 
stupid, to add to the list, guns are stupid. The human race has developed 
to the point where machinery takes priority over the lives of others. 
Religion, is one of the stupidest ideas because it enforces us to take 
lives and flesh when something that we cannot be sure about stands behind 
us "justifying" our actions. Sikhism is the one religion that I have read, 
seen, and heard about that does not discriminate. They appreciate all forms 
of life, they do not care about your sexual orientation, they do not care 
about your sex, and, they do not care whether you believe in their 
religion, they care about your health, mental and physical. This religion 
is what I believe to be the closest teaching to kindness in our world. 
"Humanity" is not even a word that describes kindness and compassion 
anymore, it is a word that describes the people of today that argue over 
petty matters such as power rather than remember that they are responsible 
for the people in their lives. The people in power do not understand the 
beautiful creativity that moves and pushes children to experience new 
things. It is the corruption of the world around them that make children 
power hungry. If children were taught with the compassion of Guru Nanak, 
Dalai-Lama, Mohatmet Gandhi, or even Charlie Chaplin this world would be a 
better place. I do not know about you people, how you live your lives, what 
you eat, when you sleep, why you say things, and especially how your brain 
works. I am not pushing, I am not telling, I am not preaching, I am 
speaking, it is your choice to read or listen, state what you think, I will 
not be ignorant of what others say. I am not a pacifistic, I believe that 
if someone wishes to hurt you, defend yourself, but to a point. The men, 
who start wars do not involve themselves in them. They tell the soldiers to 
do the work for them, "fight for freedom and your country", when the 
soldiers are really just fighting for death. Bombs, bombs do not need to 
exist, they do not have to exist when there is a world that slowly dies 
watching us hold each other at gunpoint. I realize that there are people 
that force their ideals upon others, and that defending your beliefs is 
appropriate, as long as those who do not wish to concern themselves with 
the argument do not get hurt. If dictators and presidents had no soldiers 
to command, no armies, no weapons, and no nukes, they would have to solve 
their problems with words, by talking to each other rather than blindly 
killing those who step in their way. I can never know true tragedy 
first-hand until I live the lives of those who have suffered. I am only a 
16 male playing video games through highschool, and if i can realize these 
truths, I do not understand why politicians who attend Harvard cannot 
realize that machines and technology are not what we need now, bombs, are 
not what we need now. What we need is compassion and kindness. To throw 
away bombs and to embrace the true meaning of "Humanity". I do not mind 
opinions as long as they are open minded and opinionated as I love to hear 
what people have to say. If I have not convinced, or even reached out to, a 
single number of you, I hope you will learn from this.   Charlie Chaplin 
final speech in The Great Dictator

Developing a way to achieve nuclear fission in one thing. Weaponizing it is 
another. Scientists worked on both projects. While I admire people like 
Feynman and Einstein, I can't say I feel the same for the engineers who 
have worked on biological weapons, predator drones, napalm bombs.﻿
top_comment.author: Bill P.

comments.text:
What kind of peace is that? The one where if a drone or heli pilot mistakes 
your camera for an AK or finds your movement suspicious you end up all over 
the pavement?

The reason peace has mostly been kept throughout the world is because the 
great powers fight each other economically or via proxies (e.g. Vietnam 
War, Afghanistan War). As H. Kissinger put it, using nuclear weapons is 
madness. The only reason for their existence is to deter your opponent from 
using their own.

yes yes it is and the peace has been mostly kept throughout the world

The US would have won in the Pacific Theater eventually. The atomic bomb 
drops were used to end the war sooner and as a display of force. I 
understand the necessity of the Manhattan project (Germans were working on 
the atomic bomb too), but that doesn't mean I'm happy about it. 
Furthermore, was it really necessary to drop napalm bombs and use 
flamethrowers on the Vietnamese, or deploy predator drones in the Middle 
East? That's just the US trying to show the world who's boss.
